item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: September 19
item.description: A 10th-century sculpture stolen from Uttar Pradesh and shipped to France was recently returned to India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: "Yogini", a 10th-century stone sculpture stolen from a village in Uttar Pradesh and shipped to Paris, was recently returned to India. The sculpture is on display at the National Museum in New Delhi.

item.title: Yangon, Once Frozen in Time, Inches Forward
item.description: Myanmar’s halting political progress is reflected in Yangon, a city that swells with new opportunity despite numerous problems. Three videos explore these shifts.
item.dc:creator: By CATHERINE TRAYWICK

item.title: McCain Sharply Criticizes Putin
item.description: In an online essay, he says that he is pro-Russia but delivers a blistering attack on the Russian president.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Pope Bluntly Faults Church’s Focus on Gays and Abortion
item.description: “We have to find a new balance,” Pope Francis said in the first extensive interview of his papacy, in which he sought to set a new tone for the church.
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: Pope Francis, who has said the church should be a “home for all,” on Sept. 4 in St Peter's Square at the Vatican.

item.title: Senior Egyptian Officer Is Killed in Raid on Islamists
item.description: An unidentified gunman killed a senior police officer and 10 other officers were wounded on Thursday when Egyptian security forces raided a bastion of Islamist support on the outskirts of Cairo.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: European Union Officer Is Killed in Kosovo
item.description: The victim, a Lithuanian customs officer, was part of a European mission that oversees judicial affairs in the tense region.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: India Ink: Ladies and Gentlemen, Delhi Police Is Not With You If You Are Poor
item.description: A former crime reporter explains how the Delhi police criminalizes the poor.
item.dc:creator: By SOMNATH BATABYAL
item.media:description: Delhi police personnel at the inauguration of a new set of police control room vans in New Delhi on Jan. 20

item.title: Letter From Europe: Balancing Religion and Integration
item.description: European society is changing, offering new challenges and perhaps a new assertiveness among Muslims that unsettles those who expect a degree of pliancy from their minorities.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Iran’s Leaders Signal Effort at New Thaw
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani capped a series of gestures from Iran’s ruling establishment by saying the country would never “seek weapons of mass destruction, including nuclear weapons.”
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Hassan Rouhani, the new president of Iran.

item.title: Listening Post: Through Diplomacy, Obama Finds a Pen Pal in Iran
item.description: At the core of Iran’s recent diplomatic charm offensive is an exchange of letters between President Obama and President Hassan Rouhani.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: India Ink: India Moves to Transform Its Pension System
item.description: A draft legislation aimed at reform in the pension sector, does not address the core objectives of pension — “reducing uncertainty, vulnerability and poverty in old age,” expert says.
item.dc:creator: By PAMPOSH RAINA
item.media:description: A government employee of the telegraph department at his workplace in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on July 15.

item.title: Chinese Company Shares Details of Corruption Investigation
item.description: Chinese investigators have questioned a company caught up in the inquiry into China’s biggest state-owned oil conglomerate, seizing documents and freezing accounts.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sectarian Violence Reignites in an Iraqi Town
item.description: Villagers in Diyala Province saw much death during the worst of Iraq’s carnage over the past decade, but they say what is happening now is far worse.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: More than 350 Sunni families who were forced from their homes in Muqdadiya, Iraq, by Shiite gunmen now live in this squatter camp in Diyala Province.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Greenpeace Members Held at Arctic Oil Rig
item.description: Russian border guards detained two activists from the environmentalist group Wednesday morning after they boarded an oil rig to protest drilling in the Arctic.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Extremists Take Syrian Town Near Turkey Border
item.description: A group linked to Al Qaeda routed Syrian rebel fighters and seized control of Azaz, a gateway town near Syria’s northern border with Turkey.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI

item.title: U.S. Is Asked to Hold Sudan Leader if He Visits U.N.
item.description: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, who has been charged with genocide, is seeking a visa to attend the United Nations General Assembly.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Germany’s Effort at Clean Energy Proves Complex
item.description: Germany’s plan to convert to renewable energy sources is running into problems in execution that are forcing Germans to face the costs of sticking to their principles.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and STANLEY REED
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Olaf Taeuber had to seek help last week to fend off a threat from a power company to cut off his electricity, despite his efforts to use little of it.

item.title: Russia Calls U.N. Chemical Report on Syria Biased
item.description: Saying the report was biased and incomplete, Russia hardened its stance even as it pressed ahead with a plan to disarm Syria’s government of its chemical arsenal.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: An opposition fighter rested on Tuesday at a camp in Idlib Province in northwest Syria.

item.title: Police Raid Golden Dawn Office in Athens After a Killing
item.description: The raid at the office of the Greek far-right party on Wednesday came after the fatal stabbing of an antifascist activist set off widespread protests.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Riot police officers clashed with protesters in Athens on Wednesday after the killing of Pavlos Fyssas, a leftist hip-hop singer.

item.title: Questions Swirl After Bus Plows Into Train in Canada
item.description: Speculation was widespread that the driver of a double-decker bus in Ottawa had suffered a medical emergency before the bus crashed into a train, killing six passengers and the bus driver.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Investigators at the scene of a crash involving a bus and a train in Ottawa on Wednesday. The driver was among those killed.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Shops Looted as Acapulco Recovers From Flood
item.description: Looters plundered stores on Wednesday as Acapulco struggled to recover from a flood wrought by a tropical storm that is also threatening Cabo San Lucas.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY

item.title: The Lede: Syria Releases Video of Fox News Interview With Assad
item.description: Speaking to Fox News, President Bashar al-Assad compared his use of force in Syria to American efforts to quell the Los Angeles riots in 1992.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Brazilian Court Allows Appeals for Political Figures Convicted of Corruption
item.description: The court ruling allowing the reopening of crucial aspects of the trial suggested that senior political figures convicted in a vast vote-buying scheme may not get any hard jail time.
item.category: Dirceu de Oliveira e Silva, Jose
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Morsi Speaks With Family by Phone, Lawyer Says
item.description: Mohamed Morsi, the ousted Egyptian president, had his first contact with his family since he was held in military custody and said he was in good health, his lawyer said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A supporter of the ousted Egyptian president, Mohamed Morsi, held a poster of him during a protest in Nasr City district of Cairo last week. The Muslim Brotherhood has vowed to continue protests until he is restored to power.

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,256 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
